{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3149838,"name":"Rick Lance","username":"rlance","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rlance/{size}/8537_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-21T14:47:52.842Z","cooked":"

Currently we are using Falcons for each joint in our arm and are wanting to protect them from stall damage. In looking at the chart below for the Falcon it seems like that I should be able to set my stator current limit to 30A and not risk damaging the motor. Is that a valid conclusion?

ConstantCurrent1010Ã—672 34.7 KB

Also, we at some point may switch to using the NEO motors. In my quick look at the documentation I didnâ€™t see a stator limiting function for the Spark Max. Maybe it is called something else or I just missed it.

Finally, for the BAG motor is there also a safe current for those if we use that on a claw and want to apply constant pressure to a game piece?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-02-21T14:47:52.842Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":45,"reads":424,"readers_count":423,"score":314.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":427588,"topic_slug":"protecting-arm-motors-from-damage","display_username":"Rick Lance","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/f/c/fc553f9acebae35d1e46966e15e2a462f3b40a54.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/arm-falcon-motor-stalling-at-set-position/428793/2","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Arm falcon motor stalling at set position","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26112,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/protecting-arm-motors-from-damage/427588/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3150188,"name":"Ari Meles-Braverman","username":"AriMB","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arimb/{size}/189989_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-21T23:39:21.375Z","cooked":"
rlance:

Currently we are using Falcons for each joint in our arm and are wanting to protect them from stall damage. In looking at the chart below for the Falcon it seems like that I should be able to set my stator current limit to 30A and not risk damaging the motor. Is that a valid conclusion?

Yeah that should be right.

rlance:

Also, we at some point may switch to using the NEO motors. In my quick look at the documentation I didnâ€™t see a stator limiting function for the Spark Max. Maybe it is called something else or I just missed it.

https://docs.revrobotics.com/sparkmax/gs-sm/connect-a-spark-max-over-usb#set-the-smart-current-limit
Can also be done with the CANSparkMax API

rlance:

Finally, for the BAG motor is there also a safe current for those if we use that on a claw and want to apply constant pressure to a game piece?

https://motors.vex.com/media/wysiwyg/LockedRotor_4.PNG

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-02-21T23:39:21.375Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":343,"readers_count":342,"score":88.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":427588,"topic_slug":"protecting-arm-motors-from-damage","display_username":"Ari Meles-Braverman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.revrobotics.com/sparkmax/gs-sm/connect-a-spark-max-over-usb#set-the-smart-current-limit","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Make it Spin! - SPARK MAX","clicks":7},{"url":"https://motors.vex.com/media/wysiwyg/LockedRotor_4.PNG","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"LockedRotor_4.PNG","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25012,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/protecting-arm-motors-from-damage/427588/2","custom_user_title":"FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3150214,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-22T00:08:56.948Z","cooked":"

Short of doing something absolutely crazy (i.e. completely unreasonable reduction in arm gearbox) you shouldnâ€™t find yourself running these motors anywhere near higher enough amps for long enough to be an issue. You could probably current limit at 60 amps and still be fine unless somehow you crash the arm into itself . Heck you coldd probably theoretically throw 200 amps momentarily (fractions of a second) at the motor and it will be fine thermally.

Iâ€™ll leave the actual numbers to people that know more, but if memory serves we had some falcons that we threw significantly over 100 amps at repeatedly during a match for spinning up flywheels.

(@Mark_Wasserman maybe you can confirm how high flywheel startup loads were in 2022 and 2020)

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-02-22T00:13:43.676Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":291,"readers_count":290,"score":73.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":427588,"topic_slug":"protecting-arm-motors-from-damage","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/protecting-arm-motors-from-damage/427588/3","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3150480,"name":"Rick Lance","username":"rlance","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rlance/{size}/8537_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-22T14:24:05.781Z","cooked":"
AriMB:

I saw that chart but it wasnâ€™t as easy for me to figure out as the one for the Falcon. Can you walk me through how to get the Amps Iâ€™m looking for from that BAG chart.

Thanks

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-02-22T14:24:05.781Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":254,"readers_count":253,"score":70.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":427588,"topic_slug":"protecting-arm-motors-from-damage","display_username":"Rick Lance","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26112,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/protecting-arm-motors-from-damage/427588/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3150507,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-22T15:04:56.436Z","cooked":"

Confusingly, the plot legend is uselessâ€”they should be labeled with different voltages but are all the same. You can get that info from the callouts for stall torque though. The 8V plot goes to zero (motor failure) after about 90 seconds. The 6V line doesnâ€™t have a fall-off. This means you can run a BAG at 50% duty cycle (6V) stalled essentially forever. And you can compute the current for that duty cycle for a stalled motor from the other motor parameters/curves.

If we ended up using the BAG motor for the claw, maybe we should just adjust the ratio in the gearbox until 6V gives us the cone squeeze we are looking for. Hopefully that doesnâ€™t mean it squeezes really slowly

We have successfully stalled the arm at a low enough current. Is there anything we can do about that annoying sound the Falcon makes when being stalled??? Can we at least change the pitch so that we can have our 3 joints harmonize.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-02-23T14:20:31.528Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":147,"readers_count":146,"score":59.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":427588,"topic_slug":"protecting-arm-motors-from-damage","display_username":"Alex Van Aacken","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":26112,"username":"rlance","name":"Rick Lance","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rlance/{size}/8537_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50713,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6925 Alum"},"post_url":"/t/protecting-arm-motors-from-damage/427588/8","custom_user_title":"6925 Alum","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3151152,"name":"Rick Lance","username":"rlance","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rlance/{size}/8537_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-23T14:29:05.948Z","cooked":"

When you are programming the arm for the first time and it makes that sound, it makes you want to hit the kill switch if you arenâ€™t prepared for it.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-02-23T14:29:05.948Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":147,"readers_count":146,"score":29.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":427588,"topic_slug":"protecting-arm-motors-from-damage","display_username":"Rick Lance","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26112,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/protecting-arm-motors-from-damage/427588/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3151156,"name":"ToddF","username":"ToddF","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/toddf/{size}/5508_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-23T14:36:27.626Z","cooked":"

Just to clarify, you do have your arm properly counterbalanced, correct? If you do it right, the motors are only lightly loaded when holding any position. They only ever see current when accelerating and decelerating the arm, or if you crash into something, or are against a travel hardstop. You use current limits for safety, but you should never actually be hitting those limits in normal operation.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-02-23T14:36:27.626Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":146,"readers_count":145,"score":34.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":427588,"topic_slug":"protecting-arm-motors-from-damage","display_username":"ToddF","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16376,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/protecting-arm-motors-from-damage/427588/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3151159,"name":"Rick Lance","username":"rlance","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rlance/{size}/8537_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-23T14:42:08.492Z","cooked":"

To hold the arm segments at 90 degrees currently it only takes about 1.2 volts. Donâ€™t remember the exact current draw, but it wasnâ€™t much. We arenâ€™t getting anywhere near our 30 amp limit we set.

Edit: That 1.2 volts was before we adding another 3:1 slice in the gearbox, so that would be even less now.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-02-23T15:07:50.824Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":146,"readers_count":145,"score":29.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":427588,"topic_slug":"protecting-arm-motors-from-damage","display_username":"Rick Lance","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":16376,"username":"ToddF","name":"ToddF","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/toddf/{size}/5508_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26112,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/protecting-arm-motors-from-damage/427588/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3151364,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-23T18:53:01.555Z","cooked":"
rlance:

If we ended up using the BAG motor for the claw, maybe we should just adjust the ratio in the gearbox until 6V gives us the cone squeeze we are looking for. Hopefully that doesnâ€™t mean it squeezes really slowly

Actually, Iâ€™d recommend a 15A limit rather than a 50% duty cycle. (I got the 15A from downloading the actual locked rotor data for 6V and looking at the current near the end of the run). This would let the claw move quickly when thereâ€™s less load and only slow down as you begin to compress your cone. [added] If you build with a bit of overhead, you can even use your current limit as a proxy to control clamping tension.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-02-23T19:14:33.629Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":101,"readers_count":100,"score":45.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":427588,"topic_slug":"protecting-arm-motors-from-damage","display_username":"Gus Michel II","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22335,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Somebody Else â¬›ðŸŸ«ðŸŸ¥ðŸŸ§ðŸŸ¨ðŸŸ©ðŸŸ¦ðŸŸªâ–’â–’â¬œ "},"post_url":"/t/protecting-arm-motors-from-damage/427588/12","custom_user_title":"Somebody Else â¬›ðŸŸ«ðŸŸ¥ðŸŸ§ðŸŸ¨ðŸŸ©ðŸŸ¦ðŸŸªâ–’â–’â¬œ ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3151380,"name":"Rick Lance","username":"rlance","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rlance/{size}/8537_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-23T19:11:02.646Z","cooked":"

That does sound like a much better plan. Thanks

Edit: Also, thanks for telling me how you came up with the 15A limit. Great info.
